cluster_relations.rel_desc: The austenitic structure is normally found in 300 Series austenitic stainless steels.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: AlloyScope: 300 Series stainless steels

remarks: Complements the alloy→structure relation by capturing where the structure is typically present.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Ferritic structure occurs as one phase within duplex stainless steels.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: StructureContext: part of mixed austenitic-ferritic phase balance

remarks: Redundant with the duplex→ferritic structural relation but captures the inverse perspective (where ferritic is found).

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Austenitic structure occurs as one phase within duplex stainless steels.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: StructureContext: part of mixed austenitic-ferritic phase balance

remarks: Inverse perspective of the duplex→austenitic structural relation, included for coverage of where the austenitic phase is found.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Hydrogen Induced Cracking (HIC) is described as a cracking mechanism that occurs in steels, which plausibly includes low alloy steels as a subset.

qualifiers.SpatialQualifier: on different planes in the metal / steels; may connect to the metal surface
qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: no externally applied stress is needed for formation of HIC
qualifiers.CausalHint: because of internal pressure resulting from the accumulation of hydrogen
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: CrackMechanism: stepwise internal cracks that connect adjacent hydrogen blisters; LinkMechanism: transgranular plastic shear

remarks: Relation added mainly to capture that HIC is a cracking mechanism relevant to steels, with low alloy steel treated as a representative steel family. Semantics somewhat generic; confidence reduced because the text does not explicitly name low alloy steels as HIC-susceptible.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphitization occurs in low alloy C-Mo steels containing up to 1% Mo.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: ObservationContext: field or service experience

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphite nodules are present in carbon steels as products of carbide decomposition at elevated temperatures.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Origin: decomposition of carbide phases

remarks: Subjective mapping of the pronoun “these steels” to carbon steels; 0.5Mo steels are handled in a separate relation.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphite nodules can also occur in 0.5Mo steels under elevated temperature conditions.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Origin: carbide phase decomposition associated with graphitization

remarks: Moderate uncertainty because the pronoun could be read as all previously mentioned affected steels.

args.canonical_rel_desc: A microstructural phase, degradation product, or damage mechanism occurs within or is present in a given material or alloy family.
args.justification: All listed relations describe some structure, phase, product, or cracking/degradation mechanism (austenitic or ferritic structures, HIC, graphitization, graphite nodules) being present in or occurring within a specific steel or alloy family. The existing raw relation_name is consistently 'occurs_in' and matches this semantics, so it is appropriate to standardize all of them to the canonical predicate 'occurs_in' with a generalized description.
args.remark: This canonical predicate is intentionally broad to cover both microstructural phases and damage/degradation mechanisms occurring in steel/alloy systems.

args.justification: Each relation links a phenomenon or feature (microstructural phase, cracking mechanism, degradation product or process) to a material or alloy in which it occurs. Grouping them under a class that captures occurrence of phenomena within materials provides a useful intermediate abstraction above the specific 'occurs_in' predicate.
args.remark: Covers both benign microstructural phases (austenitic, ferritic) and detrimental phenomena (HIC, graphitization, graphite nodules) as occurrences within steels and alloys.

args.justification: These relations primarily express where a phenomenon or structure is found (within a specific steel or alloy), i.e., a spatial/locational containment within a material system, rather than a causal, compositional, or hierarchical relation.
args.remark: While these edges are also thematically about degradation/microstructure, their core semantics is locational presence of a phenomenon in a material, which fits best under a SPATIALITY-oriented group.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: A microstructural phase, degradation product, or damage mechanism occurs within or is present in a given material or alloy family.
executed_decisions.justification: All listed relations describe some structure, phase, product, or cracking/degradation mechanism (austenitic or ferritic structures, HIC, graphitization, graphite nodules) being present in or occurring within a specific steel or alloy family. The existing raw relation_name is consistently 'occurs_in' and matches this semantics, so it is appropriate to standardize all of them to the canonical predicate 'occurs_in' with a generalized description.
executed_decisions.remark: This canonical predicate is intentionally broad to cover both microstructural phases and damage/degradation mechanisms occurring in steel/alloy systems.

executed_decisions.justification: Each relation links a phenomenon or feature (microstructural phase, cracking mechanism, degradation product or process) to a material or alloy in which it occurs. Grouping them under a class that captures occurrence of phenomena within materials provides a useful intermediate abstraction above the specific 'occurs_in' predicate.
executed_decisions.remark: Covers both benign microstructural phases (austenitic, ferritic) and detrimental phenomena (HIC, graphitization, graphite nodules) as occurrences within steels and alloys.

executed_decisions.justification: These relations primarily express where a phenomenon or structure is found (within a specific steel or alloy), i.e., a spatial/locational containment within a material system, rather than a causal, compositional, or hierarchical relation.
executed_decisions.remark: While these edges are also thematically about degradation/microstructure, their core semantics is locational presence of a phenomenon in a material, which fits best under a SPATIALITY-oriented group.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Stainless steels are resistant to oxidation due to their alloy content.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: MechanismType: corrosion mechanism

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Stainless steels are resistant to sulfidation due to their alloy content.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: MechanismType: corrosion mechanism

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Stainless steels resist various forms of general corrosion, beyond just oxidation and sulfidation, depending on alloy content.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Scope: other forms of corrosion beyond oxidation and sulfidation

remarks: Relation generalized from phrase 'other forms of corrosion' to entity 'general corrosion'.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Chromium, as an alloying element in stainless steels, contributes to resistance against oxidation.

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: when present as alloying element in stainless steels
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Context: chromium in stainless steel alloy matrix

remarks: Resistance is mediated via stainless steels; not direct chromium surface behavior, but captured as a causal contribution.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Chromium, as an alloying element in stainless steels, contributes to resistance against sulfidation.

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: when present as alloying element in stainless steels
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Context: chromium in stainless steel alloy matrix

remarks: Again, resistance is via its role in stainless steels rather than isolated chromium behavior.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Chromium contributes to resistance to general corrosion forms when used as an alloying element in stainless steels.

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: when present as alloying element in stainless steels; depending on the alloy content
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Scope: general corrosion (other forms of corrosion)

remarks: Relation created mainly to capture that chromium helps overall corrosion resistance; semantics slightly generalized.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Adding approximately 0.7% chromium to low alloy C-Mo steels eliminates graphitization.

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: addition of about 0.7% chromium; steels with up to 1% Mo

remarks: Material context (low alloy C-Mo steels with up to 1% Mo) added as qualifiers rather than as extra entities.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Denotes that a material is resistant to, or withstands, a specified corrosion mechanism or general corrosion form under stated conditions.
args.justification: All three relations link stainless steel directly to specific corrosion mechanisms (oxidation, sulfidation, general corrosion) with the same semantics: the alloy itself resists these mechanisms depending on alloy content.
These relations describe the resistance performance of a material (stainless steel) against various corrosion mechanisms, fitting a corrosion resistance–focused relation class.
The relations capture how a material interacts with corrosion mechanisms (it withstands or resists them), which is best modeled as an interaction between material and environment/process.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Denotes that an alloying element or factor increases the resistance of a material to a specified corrosion mechanism or general corrosion form.
args.justification: In these three relations, chromium (as an alloying element) is not itself resisting corrosion directly but causally contributing to the corrosion resistance of stainless steels against oxidation, sulfidation, and general corrosion. A canonical predicate emphasizing enhancement of resistance is appropriate.
args.remark: Normalized the more specific wording 'provides_resistance_to' to the more general predicate 'enhances_resistance_to' to cover causal contributions to corrosion resistance.

args.justification: Each relation expresses how the alloying element chromium affects the corrosion resistance of stainless steels to different mechanisms, forming a coherent class about alloying element influence on corrosion resistance.
The semantics are explicitly causal: the presence of chromium in the alloy leads to increased resistance against the specified corrosion mechanisms.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Denotes that the presence or addition of a substance or factor effectively prevents or eliminates a specified degradation process or phenomenon under given conditions.
args.justification: This relation states that adding about 0.7% chromium to low alloy C-Mo steels eliminates graphitization, which semantically corresponds to chromium preventing that degradation process.
The link captures inhibition/elimination of a metallurgical degradation process (graphitization) by an alloying addition, fitting a class about inhibiting or suppressing degradation phenomena.
The relation is explicitly causal and inhibitory: adding chromium causes graphitization to be eliminated, so a causality-oriented group is appropriate.

The relations capture how a material interacts with corrosion mechanisms (it withstands or resists them), which is best modeled as an interaction between material and environment/process.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphitization alters the microstructure of carbon steels after long-term operation, degrading their mechanical properties.

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: operation in the 800°F to 1100°F (427°C to 593°C) range
qualifiers.CausalHint: that may cause a loss in strength, ductility, and/or creep resistance
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: DamageType: mechanical property degradation

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphitization alters the microstructure of 0.5Mo steels during long-term high-temperature operation.

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: operation in the 800°F to 1100°F (427°C to 593°C) range
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: DamageType: loss in strength, ductility, and/or creep resistance

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphitization corresponds to decomposition of carbide phases into graphite nodules, effectively producing graphite nodules in the steel.
remarks: Carbide phases are not an explicit entity; relation framed between graphitization and graphite nodules to preserve transformation context.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a process or phenomenon changes the microstructure of a material.
args.justification: Both relations describe graphitization changing the microstructure of steels under long-term high-temperature operation; the existing predicate wording already matches the intended semantics and can be standardized.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a process or transformation produces a specific microstructural feature in a material.
args.justification: This relation describes graphitization as a transformation that results in graphite nodules; the core predicate is production/formation of a microstructural feature by a process.
These edges link a degradation process (graphitization) to steels whose microstructure is altered; they belong to a family of relations about changes to material microstructure.

The relation connects a phase transformation process (graphitization) with the microstructural product (graphite nodules), fitting a class of relations that express the products of phase or microstructural transformations.
Graphitization is described specifically as altering the microstructure of the steels, which is a structural modification of the material.
The process of graphitization causes the formation of graphite nodules; the emphasis is on the process producing a product, a clear causal relationship.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a process or phenomenon changes the microstructure of a material.
executed_decisions.justification: Both relations describe graphitization changing the microstructure of steels under long-term high-temperature operation; the existing predicate wording already matches the intended semantics and can be standardized.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Methyldiethanolamine and monoethanolamine are both used in amine treating to remove H2S and CO2 from hydrocarbon streams, indicating they serve similar functional roles and can be alternatives to each other.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: ApplicationContext: amine treating of hydrocarbon streams for H2S and CO2 removal

remarks: Relation created to capture that these two amine treating chemicals share the same described use; semantics are approximated as an alternative/substitute relation since no explicit comparison wording is given.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Duplex stainless steel is one of the four categories of stainless steels listed.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: CategoryType: stainless steel category

remarks: Although text just says 'duplex', entity is resolved as duplex stainless steel; relation captures the category membership.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Duplex stainless steel is a subtype/category within the broader class of stainless steels.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that two entities can be used in place of one another for the same functional role in a given application context.
args.justification: The relation describes methyldiethanolamine and monoethanolamine serving similar functional roles in amine treating and being usable as alternatives; a predicate emphasizing functional substitutability best captures this.
args.remark: Direction is arbitrary in this symmetric relation; canonical name is chosen to express functional interchangeability.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is a broader class or category that includes the object as a more specific subtype or member category.
args.justification: Here, stainless steel is explicitly described as having duplex stainless steel as one of its categories; the direction is from broader class to included subtype, so 'has_subtype' is appropriate.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is a more specific subtype or category within the broader class represented by the object.
args.justification: This relation explicitly states that duplex stainless steel is within the broader class of stainless steel; with subject=duplex and object=stainless, the canonical predicate should be the subtype-to-supertype direction.

Both relations express hierarchical taxonomic links between material classes (stainless steel and duplex stainless steel), one from class to subtype and the other from subtype to class; they belong to the same material taxonomy family.

Taxonomic subclass/superclass relations between material categories express identity-like hierarchical classification, fitting an IDENTITY-style group (covering type-subtype and class-membership structures).
The relation captures that two chemicals serve the same function in a process and can substitute for each other, which is a functional equivalence/alternative family of relations.
The connection is about how the chemicals are used in the same application context (amine treating) rather than their composition or structure, so it best fits a broad USAGE-oriented group.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that two entities can be used in place of one another for the same functional role in a given application context.
executed_decisions.justification: The relation describes methyldiethanolamine and monoethanolamine serving similar functional roles in amine treating and being usable as alternatives; a predicate emphasizing functional substitutability best captures this.
executed_decisions.remark: Direction is arbitrary in this symmetric relation; canonical name is chosen to express functional interchangeability.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: DocumentStructure: listed as peer damage mechanism categories in the same section

remarks: Relation reflects document-level grouping rather than a causal or hierarchical dependency; direction is arbitrary and used only to encode co-membership.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: DocumentStructure: co-listed as damage mechanism categories

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that two entities are co-listed or grouped together as peer categories within the same document structure (e.g., same section or list), without implying causal, hierarchical, or compositional relationships.
args.justification: All three relations describe damage mechanism categories being presented as peer sections or co-listed categories within the same document section or list. This is purely a document-structure-based co-grouping with arbitrary direction and no implied causality or hierarchy, so they share the same canonical predicate 'grouped_with'.
args.remark: Predicate is intentionally symmetric and document-structure oriented; direction of the edge is not semantically meaningful.

args.justification: Each relation instance encodes that two damage mechanisms are co-classified or co-listed as peer categories in the same part of a document, which is best modeled as a document-level co-classification/grouping relation rather than a physical or causal relation.
args.remark: Use this class for relations that arise from document structure (peer sections, tables, lists) where entities are presented as coordinate categories.

args.justification: The semantics are that the entities are associated by co-occurrence and co-listing in the same document section, without a stronger physical, causal, or hierarchical meaning, which fits a broad ASSOCIATION group.
args.remark: These edges should be interpreted as weak associative links derived from document organization.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an alloy or steel type possesses a specific metallurgical structure or phase (e.g., austenitic, ferritic, martensitic) under given conditions.
args.justification: All these relations link a steel or stainless steel category (subject) to a metallurgical structure/phase (object: austenitic, ferritic, martensitic) and are already consistently named 'has_metallurgical_structure'. The qualifiers (e.g., room temperature, mixed austenitic-ferritic) refine conditions but do not change the core predicate semantics.

Each relation expresses how a steel or alloy category is characterized by or composed of specific metallurgical phases, which is a microstructural property determining classification (austenitic, ferritic, martensitic, duplex). Grouping these under 'microstructure_relation' captures their common focus on metallurgical structure.

The broad semantic dimension here concerns the structural/microstructural characteristics of materials (metallurgical phases) rather than composition, causality, or usage. Therefore these belong in a STRUCTURE-oriented relation group.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an alloy or steel type possesses a specific metallurgical structure or phase (e.g., austenitic, ferritic, martensitic) under given conditions.
executed_decisions.justification: All these relations link a steel or stainless steel category (subject) to a metallurgical structure/phase (object: austenitic, ferritic, martensitic) and are already consistently named 'has_metallurgical_structure'. The qualifiers (e.g., room temperature, mixed austenitic-ferritic) refine conditions but do not change the core predicate semantics.

Each relation expresses how a steel or alloy category is characterized by or composed of specific metallurgical phases, which is a microstructural property determining classification (austenitic, ferritic, martensitic, duplex). Grouping these under 'microstructure_relation' captures their common focus on metallurgical structure.

The broad semantic dimension here concerns the structural/microstructural characteristics of materials (metallurgical phases) rather than composition, causality, or usage. Therefore these belong in a STRUCTURE-oriented relation group.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Welds of austenitic stainless steels may exhibit a duplex-type (austenitic-ferritic) structure, linking them conceptually to duplex stainless steels.

qualifiers.SpatialQualifier: in welds of 300 Series stainless steels
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: MicrostructureContext: weld metal/heat-affected zone duplex (austenitic-ferritic) structure

remarks: Relation created mainly to capture that welds of austenitic stainless steels can show a duplex (austenitic-ferritic) microstructure; semantic mapping to the duplex stainless steel family is approximate.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Stainless steels contain varying amounts of chromium as an alloying element.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: CompositionContext: alloy content in stainless steels

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that two alloy or steel families are conceptually linked because one can exhibit a microstructure similar to that characteristic of the other under certain process or service conditions.
args.justification: The description states that welds of austenitic stainless steels may exhibit a duplex (austenitic–ferritic) structure, conceptually linking them to duplex stainless steels. This is not strict composition or identity but a similarity/association based on microstructure; a predicate emphasizing microstructural similarity best captures this semantics.
args.remark: The link is conceptual and conditional (only in welds, and only sometimes); these nuances remain in qualifiers rather than in the canonical predicate.

args.justification: The relation connects two steel families based on the fact that one can exhibit a microstructure typical of the other (duplex-type austenitic–ferritic). This is best treated as a class of relations expressing similarity or analogy in microstructure, not direct composition or hierarchy.

The link is an associative/similarity relation (conceptual connection via possible duplex-like microstructure) rather than strict compositional, causal, or hierarchical structure. Therefore it fits the broad ASSOCIATION group.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an alloy or material contains a given chemical element as an intentional alloying constituent in its composition.
args.justification: The relation explicitly describes stainless steels containing chromium as an alloying element. A canonical predicate that expresses inclusion of an alloying element in the material composition is appropriate and consistent with the existing relation_name hint.

The relation captures that chromium is present in stainless steel as an alloying element, which is a prototypical member of a broader family of composition relations specifically about alloying additions.
The connection is about what chemical element is contained in the alloy; this is a straightforward compositional relation where chromium is part of the stainless steel composition.
